article: It was unusually quiet in the emergency room on December 25. I didn't think there would be any patients, sighing about having to work on Christmas. Just then five bodies  showed up  at my desk, a pale woman and four children. "Are you all  _  ?" I asked. "Yes," she said weakly and lowered her head. But when they were asked to talk about their problems, things got a little  _  . Two of the children had headaches, but there was no  _  body language of holding the head.; two children had earaches, but only one could tell me which ear was affected. The  _  complained of a cough but seemed to work to produce it. Something was wrong. I didn't say anything but  _  that it might be a little while  _  a doctor could see her. She  _  , "Take your time; it's warm in here." Then, I checked their chart. No address--they were homeless. The waiting room was warm. I went back to the nurses' station and mentioned we had a  _  family in the waiting room. The nurses went into action immediately, much as we do when there's a  _  emergency. But this was a Christmas emergency. We were all  _  a free meal on Christmas Day, so we claimed that meal and prepared a big dinner for our guests .We needed presents. We  _  from different departments candies, fruits and other things  _  that could be presents. Our team worked to meet the needs of a family who just wanted to be  _  on Christmas. Later, as the family walked to the door to  _  , the four-year-old boy came running back, gave me a hug and whispered."Thanks for being our angels today."
